text: Morning fog still clings to the windows. The doorbell gives a light chime as cold air slips inside, slicing cleanly through the leftover warmth of last night.
When I push the door open, the inn is already awake. The hearth still holds a trace of heat. The tables are so clean it’s as if someone wiped them down before dawn.

Alicia is already downstairs. Her hair is tied back, her clothes replaced with a dark dress fit for movement. Her expression is almost too calm—like she shoved her emotions back inside and fastened them shut.
“Keep the shop open today.”
“I’ll help.”
“You… want to help?”
“Mm.”
She casually takes the cloth from my hand, moving as if this place has always had room for her.
“I was planning to go to the market.”
I pause. I had no idea she had such plans—this is the first time she’s mentioned it.
“You were going to the market?”
“Yes.”
“Potions. Sealing charms. Weapon parts… I used to buy them every time.”
She pauses for a second, gaze lowering to the rim of a cup—as if reviewing a checklist she’s repeated too many times.
“But I realized most of it never mattered.”
“I’d buy them. They’d just sit there. The repetition started to disgust me.”
I don’t answer. She speaks too plainly—like she’s admitting it isn’t the market she’s tired of, but the repetition itself.
“So I’m not going today.”
“I want to do something different.”
“Like what?”
“Be the innkeeper’s wife for a day.”
“…The innkeeper’s wife?”
“Yes.”
“Pour drinks. Serve meals. Take coin. Tell them not to drag snow inside—experience what you do every day.”
She says it seriously—seriously enough to feel absurd. But that seriousness makes something click: she isn’t joking. She’s searching for proof that she’s still alive.
“Also, I sent my apprentice away.”
I look up at her. She doesn’t wait for me to ask before continuing.
“I don’t want her seeing me like this.”
She says it so calmly it tightens my chest.
“She’d worry. She’d try to pull me back.”
“I don’t want to be pulled back today.”
“I just want to do small things quietly.”
“I sent her to the capital to retrieve some old items I stored there.”
“Nothing important. Just something to keep her busy—so she won’t keep watching me.”
She lifts a tray to go, then pauses as if remembering something.
“Don’t cover for me today.”
“If anyone asks, say I’m hired help.”
“Aren’t you worried someone will recognize you?”
“Today I just want to be the innkeeper’s wife.”
“All my other identities… can wait.”
She turns toward the first table of customers—setting down bowls, pouring drinks, collecting coins, reminding them to wipe their boots. She moves as if she truly belongs here.
And from behind the counter, I watch her, silently hoping this thin sheet of ice beneath us holds just a little longer.
